awd_titl_txt: Robust Optimization of Nonlinear Dynamical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The increasing emphasis on robust system designs for manufacturing, defense, and energy applications, among others, is motivating design engineers to use high-fidelity models that account for complex nonlinear behavior and uncertainty in parameter values. This research project will develop novel methods and easy-to-use software for engineers to account for uncertainty at the design stage.  These products will dramatically improve the design capabilities in nearly every industry, resulting in safer, more reliable, more robust, and more cost-effective designs of engineered systems.  As part of this research project a graduate student will be trained in cutting edge research.  Also, a new module on the robust design of dynamical systems will be developed to introduce formal dynamical systems under uncertainty to systems engineers from industry through a graduate online course on Uncertainty Analysis, Robust Design, and Optimization.

The objective of this research project is to solve the robust design problem for systems modeled as initial value problems which is formulated as a bi-level, max/min, and/or semi-infinite optimization problem. Solving this problem requires establishing new theoretical mathematics, numerical analysis, and high-speed software implementations for combining dynamic simulation and deterministic global optimization. The development of McCormick-based relaxations of implicit functions is proposed for use within deterministic global optimization frameworks for global bounding information. These developments will be implemented in a software library written in the Julia programming language for high speed and accessibility. Improved systems design results in greater safety and security which benefits society by reducing the impacts of catastrophic operational failures or eliminating them altogether. Improved designs also result in reduced production costs and reduced environmental impact through efficiency improvements which directly benefit society by reducing costs of products (e.g., commodities, energy, consumer goods, transportation, etc.).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The reliability and safety of engineered systems are paramount to modern society. A robust system is one that can mitigate the effects of uncertainty and perform as intended and, in turn, improve reliability and safety. One example of such a system is a commercial aircraft that can sustain flight and safe/comfortable cabin environment conditions over a wide range of flight conditions and weather. As systems become more advanced and increasingly complex, formal mathematical approaches and software tools are needed to aid engineers in the development and testing methods to improve the robustness of systems. Of particular interest within the scope of this project is how complex systems behave over time (i.e., dynamical systems) while being subject to various sources of uncertainty and, specifically, how such systems behave in the face of worst-case uncertainty (i.e., uncertainty that impacts system performance in the worst way). The primary objective was to develop new methods and tools to account for uncertainty and complex nonlinear system behavior in the design of engineered systems.

The novel intellectual contributions made with this project include new algorithms, computational tools and software, and new models and modeling approaches. Formal mathematical programming (optimization) approaches underpin these contributions. As such, one significant product is the creation and release of an open-source software package for rigorously solving nonconvex optimization problems that arise in a breadth of domains from healthcare to traditional chemical engineering. Prior to this, no such general, open-source solver existed and, what's more, our solver has been demonstrated in peer-reviewed publications and academic conferences to perform competitively with the best-in-class commercial alternatives while also supporting a broader class of mathematical models and usage cases.

With our open-source solver serving as the foundation, several advances were made in the development of new methods for the robust design of nonlinear dynamical systems. The first major advancement was the development of several new computational methods to enable the solution of optimization problems that involve an especially difficult class of dynamical systems models, called stiff systems. From there, new methods were developed for solving robust design problems with models that also include mathematical components from popular machine learning approaches. These efforts required new theoretical mathematical developments to improve the computational efficiency of the optimization solver when these types of models are involved. With these new theoretical developments and the robust design methodology, we were able to show how machine learning models can be used safely with physics-based models to ensure that they are not mistakenly being used outside of their domains of validity (i.e., used to extrapolate beyond where they are valid). The result is that we've established a methodology for using machine learning models in engineering design applications in a safe manner that prohibits violation of their underlying assumptions. Furthermore, we demonstrated this methodology beyond traditional chemical engineering in a healthcare application whereby physics-based models and machine learning models were used to determine therapeutic regimens to maximize certain patient health outcomes.

This project directly supported the training of three PhD students in the department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at the University of Connecticut. This project also provided research training experiences for 10 undergraduate students, who almost all went on to pursue PhD degrees. Furthermore, the open-source methods and software developed in this project were released publicly and continue to be maintained. These software tools have been disseminated internationally with several other researchers across disciplines adopting and incorporating them within their own research. As such, some of the main research products of this project help serve the needs of the broader community of researchers and practitioners.
